## 1. Summary:
The discussion focuses on implementing cross-platform interactions in a VR application. hiroP was seeking solutions for handling interactions (clicks) in VR and mobile environments. Ashxn provided guidance on using the "action" node system, which works across all platforms including mobile and VR, as opposed to pointer/reticle events that only work on desktop. The action system provides a "press and hold" UI with a circle indicator on desktop, a hand button on mobile, and trigger controls in VR. This system is described as better UX for general users, while pointer events are more suitable for UI screens. hiroP successfully implemented this solution and got it working across platforms, expressing enthusiasm about the progress despite the simple cube-based implementation.

## 2. FAQ:
Q: What's the state of interactions (clicks) within VR and on mobile in the project? (asked by hiroP) A: Use the "action" node which works on all devices including mobile and VR; pointer/reticle events currently only work on desktop (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Is the actions thing the "holding down e" or "press and hold - circle appears" UI? (asked by hiroP) A: Yes! On mobile you get a little hand button that pops up when near an action, on VR you use the triggers (answered by Ashxn)

## 1. Summary
The discussion centers on Hyperfy's development direction, with philbert offering critical feedback about the platform's current trajectory. Philbert argues that Hyperfy should focus on developer experience by enabling local development with IDE integration rather than building in-world editors. They suggest prioritizing features like automated networking, easy deployment, and AI-assisted development to attract more developers. Philbert expresses concern about the lack of progress on cross-world identity and discovery features in Hyperfy v2, noting that the platform repository hasn't been updated in three months. They advocate for either delivering on the decentralized metaverse vision quickly or pivoting to meet current demand in the Three.js game development space. Philbert shares their experience building a game (pewbet.fly.dev) and highlights pain points in the current development workflow, including lack of version control and manual code copying between IDE and scripts. The conversation reveals tension between Hyperfy's long-term vision and the need for short-term adoption to ensure sustainability.
